Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of UHV SPM-TERS in situ Characterization Interfaced with UHV Sputtering-Atomic Layer Deposition System
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award supports instrument development at the University of Kansas Center for Research Inc. The instrument is an ultra-high-vacuum scanning probe microscopy-tip enhanced Raman spectroscopy characterization chamber integrated with an existing UHV sputtering-atomic layer deposition (ALD). The objective is to provide unique, state-of-the-art research infrastructure that would allow in situ fabrication and characterization of structural, chemical and physical properties at surfaces and interfaces with nanometer resolution and surface dynamics up to femtosecond temporal resolution. This instrument will directly benefit research in quantum device physics, nanomaterials, energy, and biomaterials. It will significantly advance fundamental knowledge in the pursuit of answers to the following major challenge in basic science: How do we design and perfect atom- and energy-efficient syntheses of revolutionary new forms of matter with tailored properties? The instrument will enable research designed to lead to the development of novel nanomaterials for quantum devices and solar energy harvesting and storage. The unique capability of this instrument will allow researchers, for the first time, to investigate correlation between the structural, physical and chemical properties of the Josephson tunnel junctions, which are the heart of superconducting qubits-building blocks of quantum computers. Quantum computation enabled by high-performance superconducting qubits has the potential to revolutionize information processing. The solar energy research enabled will lead to methods for increasing solar energy capture efficiency in artificial or hybrid systems for long-term electricity production for large-scale and cost-effective renewable fuel production. Further, novel low cost and high performance nano-structured photovoltaic devices for solar energy conversion will be developed. In addition, ALD grown materials will be explored for improved energy storage devices, such as supercapacitors and batteries.

This Major Research Instrumentation award supports instrument development at the University of Kansas Center for Research Inc. The instrument is a novel ultra-high-vacuum scanning probe microscopy-tip enhanced Raman spectroscopy (UHV SPM-TERS) characterization chamber integrated with an existing UHV sputtering-atomic layer deposition system. This integrated UHV growth-characterization system will enable in situ topographic, electrical, and chemical characterization, structural, electronic and optical properties of materials. Researchers will acquire fundamental understanding essential to developing novel functional materials for quantum devices and energy applications. In addition, the instrument will also support researchers in sensors, catalysis, and bioengineering. The anticipated outcomes/breakthroughs enabled by the instrumentation will lead to the development of novel and viable quantum-information and energy-related technologies with national and global impact. Existing education and outreach activities at the University of Kansas and the collaborating institutions will be leveraged by the instrumentation. Specifically, these activities will produce a unique and diverse future workforce in science and engineering, particularly in the quantum information and energy fields. Existing partnerships with minority-serving institutions, such as Haskell Indian Nations University, will promote diversity in recruiting and effective training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Major Research Instrumentation award funded the development of in situ (without breaking vacuum) characterization approaches of ultra-high vacuum scanning probe microscopy and tip-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (UHV SPM-TERS) interfaced with ultra-high vacuum physical vapor deposition and atonic layer deposition (UHV PVD-ALD).  This integrated UHV growth-characterization system, as the first in the nation,  has enabled in situ topographic, electrical, and chemical characterization for correlation of structural, electronic and optical properties of nanomaterials and thin films, and led to development of novel functional materials and structures for quantum devices and energy applications.

Quantum computing is one of the focuses of this research and detecting defects and eliminating them via growth control in ultrathin tunnel barriers in superconducting quantum bits (qubits) that are based on Josephson junctions will  remove a major roadblock on the way to building scalable quantum computers through development of defect-free tunnel barriers. Magnetic nonvolatile memory is another focus of this research for high performance and high energy efficiency data storage for regular computing and advanced computing (quantum, neuromorphic). The energy researchers can address critical issues facing the utilization of solar-based renewable energy including energy capture at the nanoscale by natural and artificial photosynthetic complexes, and solar energy conversion by nanoscale materials and devices focusing on photovoltaic processes.    

Intellectual Merit: Foremost, the UHV SPM-TERS in situ characterization capabilities integrated with the UHV PVD-ALD system has provided a unique, state-of-the-art research infrastructure that would allow researchers to directly probe the surface/interfacial properties at nanometer spatial resolution and surface dynamics up to femtosecond temporal resolution. This instrumentation has  significantly advanced fundamental knowledge in the pursuit of answers to the following major challenge in basic science: How do we design and perfect atom- and energy-efficient syntheses of revolutionary new forms of matter with tailored properties? The funded research has led to the design and development of novel nanomaterials for quantum devices and solar energy harvesting and storage. The unique capability of this instrument  allows researchers, for the first time, to investigate correlation between the structural, physical and chemical properties of the Josephson tunnel junctions, which are the heart of superconducting qubits-building blocks of quantum computers. Quantum computation enabled by high-performance superconducting qubits has the potential to revolutionize information processing. The solar energy research enabled will lead to methods for increasing solar energy capture efficiency in artificial or hybrid systems for long-term electricity production for large-scale and cost-effective renewable fuel production. Further, novel low cost and high performance nano-structured photovoltaic devices for solar energy conversion has developed.  In addition, ALD grown materials have been explored for improved energy storage devices, such as supercapacitors and batteries.

  

Broader Impacts: The outcomes/breakthroughs enabled by the the NSF MRI funded instrumentation has lead to the development of novel and viable energy-related technologies with national and global impact. The leading-edge research facility has helped in attracting top-quality students, postdoctoral fellows and faculty in several disciplines. Some of them have completed their PhD studies/postdoc researches and are now emplyed by high tech companies, such as Intel, IBM, Honeywell and high education institutions or national labs.  The instrument has also extended the research collaborations, particularly with industry, towards novel renewable energy solutions, microelectronics and advanced computing. Education and outreach activities have been leveraged by the instrumentation. Specifically, these activities have  produced a unique and diverse future workforce in science and engineering. The several women on this team, both at the leadership and researcher levels, and the existing partnerships with minority-serving institutions, further promote diversity in recruiting and effective training.
